div.l: To Sauen his Astate of ȝemanrie
And she was proude and peert as is apie
A ful feire sight was it vpon hem twoo
On holy daies byforn hir͗e wold he goo
Wiþ his typet bounden aboute his hede
And she come aftere in a gite of rede
And Symkyn had hosen of þe same
þer durst no wiȝt clepe hur͗e but dame
Was noon so hardy þat went by þe way
Þat wiþ hir͗e dorst ones rage or play
But if he wold be sclayn of Symkyn
Wiþ panade and wiþ knyf or boydekyn̄
For Ielous folk bene perylous euermoo
Algates þei wolde her wyues wenden soo
And eke for she was somdell smot̉erlich
She was as digne as water in a dissh dich
As ful of hoker and of bismare
Hire þouȝt þat a lady shuld hir͗e spare
What for her kynrede and her nortelrie
Þat she had lerned in þe Nonerie
A douȝtere had þei bitwene hem twoo
Of xxᵗⁱ ȝere wiþ outen ony moo
Sauyng a childe þat was of half ȝere age
In cradel it lay and was a ꝓpropre page
This wenche thik and wel ygrowe was
Wiþ Camoys nose and eyen as grey as glas
Wiþ buttokes brode and brestes rounde ⁊and hie
But riȝt faire was hur͗e heor I wil not lye
¶ The ꝑperson of þe toune for she was so faire
In pʳurpoos was to make hir͗e his aire
Boþ of his Catell and of his messuage
And straunge he made it of hur͗e mariage
His pʳurpoos was to bystowe hir͗e hie
Into som worþi blood of Auncetrie
For holy churches good most be despended
On holy chirche blood þat is descended
